newsitem.title: FRANCE: French judges sent note on madcow probes.
newsitem.headline: French judges sent note on madcow probes.

text.p: France's justice ministry said on Monday it had sent a note to public prosecutors laying down guidelines for prosecution into offences linked to the madcow disease.
The daily Le Monde published a circular sent on July 30 by minister Jacques Toubon, which outlined regulations and penal sanctions.
"Major public health issues are at stake. It is obvious that the judiciary has an eminent role to play in this respect," Toubon was quoted as writing.
The document, confirmed by a ministry spokesman, mentioned possible prosecution for violation of a French June ban on British animal feed containing bonemeal.
It followed an experts' recommendation to ban feed containing animal parts from countries with a high incidence of mad cow disease, or bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE).
Disclosure that Britain authorised massive exports of animal feed containing ground-up animal parts, after banning its use at home in 1988, provoked outrage in France.
The note said there might also be grounds for prosecution if consumers were misled on the origin of meat, and if health certificates were forged, among others.
Concern over the safety of animal feed has escalated since March, when Britain reported a suspected link between mad cow diseased and the deadly Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) in humans.
